Biography of Fazang of Foshoujiji Temple in Luoyang during the Zhou Dynasty. Fazang, Shi, was also called Xian Shou. His surname was Kang, and he was from Kang Ju.

His demeanor was extraordinary and upright, and his sharp wisdom was unparalleled. He traveled to Chang'an and fully displayed his talents. He later participated in the selection of famous monks for doctrinal studies.
When Master Xuanzang was translating scriptures, Fazang first joined the team. Later, he became a scribe, proofreader, and editor, and his insights were different from those in the translation hall.
During the reign of Empress Wu Zetian, he was at the forefront of the translation team.
Åšiká¹£Änanda brought the Sanskrit version of the Huayan Sutra and translated the new sutra together with Yijing and Fuli.
He also served as a proofreader for the translation hall of Yijing, together with Shengzhuang and Dayi.
In the past, Du Shun of Dunhuang transmitted the Huayan Dharma Realm Contemplation to his disciple Zhiyan, who lectured on this Jin translation.
Zhiyan passed it on to Fazang, who lectured on the new Huayan Sutra for Empress Wu Zetian.

When it came to the meaning of the celestial net, the ten layers of profound gates, the gate of the ocean seal samÄdhi, the gate of the meaning of the six characteristics in harmony, and the gate of the realm of universal vision, all of these chapters on meaning are the general and specific meaning nets of the Huayan Sutra, and the Empress was confused and undecided about this.

Fazang then pointed to the golden lion on the imperial throne as an analogy, and wrote a chapter on the meaning gates, which was concise and easy to understand, called the Golden Lion Chapter, listing the general and specific characteristics of the ten gates. The Empress then became enlightened to its meaning.

He also devised a skillful means for those who could not understand, setting up ten mirrors facing each other in the eight directions, with one above and one below, about ten feet apart, placing a Buddha image in the center, and illuminating it with a torch, with the reflections of the images intermingling.
The learners thus understood the meaning of the inexhaustible interpenetration of the Buddha lands.
Zang's skillful guidance and transformation were all of this kind.
However, he was still unable to abandon the task of translation and propagation, because it was the basis for the imperial faith and the support of the monastic community.

When the Indian monks finished translating, the emperor, on the eighth day of the tenth month in the second year of the Shengli era (1001), ordered Zang to lecture on the great sutra at Foguoji Temple. When he reached the chapter on the World of the Flower Treasury, the lecture hall and the ground of the temple all shook. The chief monk Hengjing reported this in a memorial.
The imperial edict said:
Yesterday, I requested you to expound the subtle words and proclaim the secret teachings.
When it was first translated, he dreamed of sweet dew as an auspicious sign;
On the day of the lecture, he sensed the earth shaking as a sign.
This is the Tathagata's manifestation, in accord with the text of the nine assemblies;
How can I, a mediocre person, dare to take credit for the six kinds of shaking?
Reading your letter, I am both delighted and worried.
His being valued by the emperor is truly not false. Therefore, the Huayan school entrusted Chengguan, and pushed Zang as the third patriarch.
He wrote the Commentary on the Heart Sutra of Prajnaparamita, which was valued by the time and circulated throughout the world.
Is he also called the National Preceptor Kangzang?
Tang Dynasty Biography of Hengjing of Yuquan Temple in Jingzhou, Tang Dynasty Biography of Hengjing of Yuquan Temple in Jingzhou, Shi Hengjing, whose surname was Wen, was a person from Dangyang.
In the twenty-second year of the Zhenguan era, he was ordained by imperial decree. He listened and studied the Tripiá¹­aka. He could recite it after hearing it once, and practiced as it was taught.
At first, the Vinaya Master was affiliated with the Vinaya school. Later, he entered Yuzhouan Temple on Fuzhou Mountain and followed Chan Master Zhizhe to study the gate of calming and contemplation.
Ten li south of the temple, he established a separate hermitage called Longhsing.
During the reigns of Empress Wu Zetian and Emperor Zhongzong, he was thrice summoned to the inner palace for offerings as a preceptor for receiving the precepts.
In the third year of the Jinglong era, he petitioned to return to the mountain, and the emperor approved his request.
An edict was issued to the Secretariat, the Chancellery, and the scholars to hold a vegetarian feast at the inner temple of Liguang Palace.

Previously, more than twenty eminent monks and practitioners of both learning and practice were summoned from all over the country. They constantly cultivated merit in the inner palace. At this time, the feast was dispersed, and Jing, Jun, and Xuanzang were each sent back to their hometowns.

The emperor personally composed a poem, and the scholars responded with their own poems. They included several people such as Li Qiao, the Minister of the Secretariat, and Li Xi, the Court Gentleman for Ceremonials.
At that time, Jing and the others held the poems and walked with their staffs, and the world honored them.
Jing wrote the Treatise on Following the Meaning in two fascicles, the Treatise on Embracing the True Dharma in seven fascicles, and the Treatise on Buddha-Nature in two fascicles.
Those who studied his teachings received it like thirsty people receiving water.
On the twenty-fifth day of the ninth month in the first year of Xiantian, he passed away at his residence, at the age of seventy-nine.
His disciples buried him on the western hill of the temple.
Xi said:
How far apart were Jiangling Xuanzang and the Tripiá¹­aka Master in terms of their appearance and demeanor?
However, their names were the same but their realities were different, just as Lin Xiangru was feared by the powerful Qin, while Ma Xiangru made Yang Xiong yearn for him.
Then, each had their own strengths and weaknesses, which can also be seen.

Tang Dynasty, Songshan Shaolin Temple Yixing Biography, Tang Dynasty, Songshan Shaolin Temple Yixing Biography, Shi Yixing, secular surname Zhang, from Julu, original name Sui, was a descendant of Tang Dynasty's Minister of State Gong Jin, the Marquis of Tan State.
At the age of 10, he was extraordinary, intelligent, and sharp, with the demeanor of an elder.
He did not need to read a book twice to memorize it.
He then encountered Chan Master Puzhao, who had many followers practicing Chan. He realized the impermanence of the world and took refuge with Puzhao as his teacher, leaving home to become a monk.
He recited the sutras and Dharma teachings with precision.
Master Puzhao once held a grand assembly, with monks from far and near arriving as scheduled, totaling over a thousand people.

At that time, the recluse Lu Hong was living in seclusion on another peak. He was highly regarded and well-versed in learning. The imperial court repeatedly offered him the position of Pu Lun, but he declined and did not take up the post.
The organizers of the grand assembly first requested Hong to write a guiding text to praise the local shrine.
On that day, Hong took out the text from his sleeve and placed it on the table.
When the bells and chants were completed, Hong said to Master Puzhao:

I have written several hundred thousand words, moreover the characters are obscure and the text is ancient, I request a clear and quick person to recite it, I will need to point to it face to face and pass it on.
Master Ji called out to Xing, who took the paper, read it with a smile, and put it back on the desk.
Hong found it strange that he was so light-hearted.
When the monks gathered in the hall, Xing rolled up his sleeves and went forward, reciting the text with a loud voice, not missing a single word.
Hong stared at him for a long time, sighing in admiration, and said to Master Ji again:
You cannot teach him, you should let him travel to study.
From then on, there were few famous teachers of the three studies whom he did not consult.
He then went to Dangyang, where he met Monk Zhen, who had just completed the preface to the Vinaya Piá¹­aka, and deeply understood the Vinaya.

However, he was also well-versed in the books on yin and yang and divination, and studied all of them in detail. He searched for and learned various calculation methods, traveling thousands of miles to consult with famous people.
He finally arrived at Guoqing Temple on Mount Tiantai and saw a courtyard with dozens of old pine trees, the gate leaning against a flowing stream, quiet and secluded.
He stood at the gate and heard the sound of counting beads in the courtyard, the sound of cha cha.
The monk said to his attendant:
Today, a disciple will come from afar to seek my arithmetic method. According to my calculations, he should have arrived at the gate, but will there be no one to guide him?
He then removed one counting bead.
He also said to his attendant:
If the water in front of the gate flows back to the west, the disciple will arrive.
Following his words, Xing entered and bowed, requesting the Dharma, and was fully taught the method. The water in front of the gate flowed east again.
From then on, his fame spread far and wide, and he was greatly respected by officials and nobles.
Emperor Xuanzong heard of him and issued an edict to summon him. He said to Xing:
What abilities do you have?
He replied:
I can only memorize things, I have no other strengths.

The Emperor then ordered an official to take the palace records to show them to him. He went through them all, covered the original text, and memorized them with precision and fluency, as if he had practiced them before.
After chanting several pages, the Emperor involuntarily bowed down and said:
The Master is truly a sage.
He sighed in admiration for a long time.
He then summoned him for regular audiences and had him divine calamities and blessings, as if pointing to his palm. His words were mostly beneficial.
At that time, Xing Hepo, a man of the Way, was unfathomable. He once said to Yin Yin:
Master Yixing is truly a sage.
Lu Hong of the Han Dynasty created a calendar, saying:
'After 800 years, it will be off by one day, and then a sage will correct it.'
The time period is now over.
When the Great Derivation Calendar came out, it corrected the errors. The words of Lu Hong can be trusted.
Who else but a sage could have foreseen this!
He also studied the secret mudras of the Vajra Tripiá¹­aka, ascended the Buddha altar, and received the Dharma King's treasure;
He also translated the Vairocana Buddha Sutra with the Tripiá¹­aka Master Amoghavajra, opening the Buddha's country in the future.
In transmitting the Secret Treasury, he must have reached the profound source.
The emperors Ruizong and Xuanzong both invited him to enter the Inner Court of Erudition, and soon ordered him to reside in Xingshan Temple.

The sutras he translated were finally annotated in seven fascicles, and he also wrote the Sixty Fascicle Vinaya Collection, the One Fascicle Record of the ÅšÄkya Clan, and the Fifty-Two Fascicle Kaiyuan Great DhyÄna Calendar.
The calendar was included in the Tang History Calendar and Rituals section, and was considered an imperishable classic.
He also created a celestial globe with yellow and red paths made of iron, which he produced in the courtyard.
Next, there was an old woman named Wang, who lived next door. In the past, she often supported the poor, and when the monk became famous, she always thought of repaying her kindness.
One day, she bowed and said:
My son has killed someone and will be executed.
Moreover, the master is highly respected by the emperor, so I beg you to petition for a reduction of his sentence, so that he can serve the remaining years of my life as a mother.
She cried like this several times. Xing said:
How can there be a case where someone sentenced to death by the state can be pardoned by petition?
He ordered the attendant monks to give her some money and let her go elsewhere to make plans.
The old woman scolded with her hands akimbo:
I lived next door, providing for each other, holding and nursing you when you were a baby.
When you grew up, how could you forget this kindness?
Xing's heart was full of love, and he was unhappy all night.
Then, after finishing his calculations, he summoned the attendants and warned them:
You all take a cloth bag to a quiet place in a certain ward. At noon, sit and wait. If you find any living creatures, put them in the bag and quickly return.
The next day, sure enough, there was a sow leading seven piglets. The attendants divided up and chased them. The sow ran off, but they caught the piglets and returned.
They had already prepared a large jar, and chased each one into it, closed the lid, sealed the mouth with six layers of mud, recited some Sanskrit spells, and stopped.
At dawn, the eunuch issued an edict to ask about it, saying:
The Bureau of Astronomy reported:
'Last night, the seven seats of the Northern Dipper stars were completely invisible. What is the reason?'
He replied:
In the past, during the Later Wei dynasty, the planet Ying was lost, and until now, the imperial carriage cannot be seen.
This is a great warning from Heaven to Your Majesty.
Even ordinary men and women who are not in their proper places will cause frost and drought. Only those with abundant virtue can avert it.
Those who are deeply moved by it should bury withered bones!
The Buddhist gate uses the compassionate mind to subdue all demons. The humble monk's humble opinion is no different from a great amnesty for the world.
Emperor Xuanzong followed his advice.
That night, he reported that one star in the Big Dipper was visible, and after seven nights, it returned to normal. His divination skills were unfathomable.
Moreover, during the Kaiyuan era, there was a severe drought. The emperor ordered him to pray for rain, saying:
You will obtain a vessel with a dragon-shaped pattern on it, and then you can bring rain.
He ordered an official to inspect all the vessels in the inner treasury. They all said they were not suitable.
After several days, he pointed to an ancient mirror with a coiled dragon on the handle and said joyfully:
This is a true dragon.
He then brought it into the ritual arena, and it rained in one day.
His extraordinary skills and spiritual responses were like this.
Emperor Xuanzong, in the Daming Palace, casually and secretly asked about the auspiciousness of the state and the end of the imperial reign, and the master responded with other words.
The emperor continued to inquire, and he finally said:
Your Majesty will have a journey of 'ten thousand miles'.
He also said:
The state will ultimately be auspicious.
The Emperor was greatly delighted.
He also gave the Emperor a golden box, shaped like a ping-pong ball, which contained something that made a sound when shaken, but could not be opened. He said:
Open it in an emergency.
When the Emperor went to Shu, he forgot about it in the Cang Huang Palace. When he arrived in Chengdu, he suddenly remembered and opened it, and it contained a piece of dried ginger.
The Emperor said:
This medicine is produced here. The master knew that when I encountered difficulties and went to Shu, I would be 'at peace'.
He also saw the Wanli Bridge and said:
The words of Yixing are truly divine.
He ordered an official to burn incense and make an offering to it, and then announced his gratitude.

When Emperor Zhaozong first ascended the throne, he enfeoffed Yixing as the King of Ji. By the time of his son, King De, the Tang Dynasty was destroyed by the Liang, fulfilling Yixing's words that the altars and fields will ultimately be 'at peace'.
In the ninth month of the fifteenth year of Kaiyuan, he was gravely ill at Huayan Temple. He was about to be carried to the temple to say goodbye, but stopped when he felt slightly better.
Xuanzong dreamed that night of looking down on Chan Master [Shenxiu's] abode, seeing a rope bed, paper partitions, and open doors. Upon waking, he inquired and found it to be exactly as he had seen.
He then ordered the famous virtuous ones of the capital to hold a great Dharma assembly to perform prayers for blessings. His life-threatening illness slightly improved.
His favor and love were like this.

On the eighth day of the tenth month, he followed the imperial carriage to Xin'an. He had no ailments and did not utter a single word. Suddenly he bathed in fragrant water, changed his clothes, sat cross-legged in right mindfulness, and peacefully showed his passing.
One says: After bidding farewell to Xuanzong, he came east in front of the imperial carriage to Songshan to pay homage to his original teacher, and then passed away.
At that time, Henan Yin Pei Kuan was just visiting Shenxiu. Shenxiu said:
I have a little matter and have not had time to chat with the Great Yin.
Please wait and rest for now.
Kuan then dismissed his followers and stayed in a side room, waiting to see what Shenxiu would do.
He saw the pure and proper hall, burning incense and sitting in silence, as if waiting for something.
In a short while, he knocked on the door and called out in succession:
The Heavenly Master, Monk Yixing has arrived. The monk is called Heavenly Master, seen here for the first time, meaning the Emperor's Teacher.
Yixing entered, with a rather hurried appearance. He bowed at Shibei's feet and whispered in his ear. His expression became even more respectful.
Shibei just nodded and said:
There is nothing unacceptable.
After speaking, he bowed again. He spoke and bowed three times. Shibei only said, Yes, yes, there is nothing unacceptable.
After Yixing spoke, he descended the steps and entered the southern room, closing the door himself.
Shibei then slowly called out to his attendant:
Quickly ring the bell. Yixing has already entered nirvana.
The attendants rushed to look and saw him sitting with his eyes closed, his hand covering his breath, already gone.
The disciples of the four groups wailed like the Wei River, shaking the mountains and valleys. He was then stopped at Wuxiang Temple.
From the end to the burial, a total of three weeks passed, but his nails did not change, his beard and hair grew longer, and his facial expression was joyful, which amazed the assembly.
The Emperor read the report and was deeply saddened, saying:
The Chan Master has left me, I deeply mourn him!
The funeral was provided by the government, and he was buried at Tongrenyuan, with the posthumous title of Great Wisdom Chan Master.
The Emperor composed a stele inscription, which was honored by all Buddhist disciples.
Biography of Zhi-sheng of Xichongfu Temple in Jingzhao, Tang Dynasty, Biography of Zhi-sheng of Xichongfu Temple in Jingzhao, Tang Dynasty, Shi Zhi-sheng, whose place of origin is unknown.

Biography of Xuan Yi of Huayan Temple in Jingzhao, Tang Dynasty. Biography of Xuan Yi of Huayan Temple in Jingzhao, Tang Dynasty. Shi Xuan Yi, whose surname was Dou, was a distant relative of Emperor Xuanzong Shenwu.

His branches and leaves were luxuriant, unmatched by others in the capital. His cousins and nephews often held official positions, either maintaining their simplicity and elegance or competing with each other in official glory.

Yi was a person of outstanding appearance, elegant and detached from worldly affairs. He understood the traces of form and emptiness and reached the field of true tranquility. He regarded coarse food as fine delicacies and regarded the imperial throne as a mere plaything.
Later, he joined the monastic order and pursued advanced studies. He read through the secret treasury and fragrant stupas, understanding their principles.
One day, he sighed and said:

Since the passing of the Sage, the scriptures have been disordered, sometimes only the five summers are preserved, or they are mixed with the Lu and Yu. Moreover, the manuscripts have been stolen and circulated, losing their original order.

If the chapters are lost like the missing pages of a book, it is like the Liji losing its sequence, becoming increasingly divergent and confusing, and unable to be restored. If there is one such error, the proper order will be disrupted!

Thus, he based himself on the catalogs compiled in ancient and modern times, and examined various scriptures. The texts he had read filled his desk, and the scrolls he had accumulated overflowed his room.
For variant characters, he would carefully examine their meanings and sort them out. For different chapter sequences, he would unravel their principles and organize them.
The years passed, and his achievements were accomplished.
If one's mind is not as firm as metal or stone, and one's will not as solid as ice or frost, how can one attain this?
Having compiled the subject categories, it is indeed orderly and well-organized. A total of thirty fascicles, called the Calendar of the Extensive Categories of the Buddhist Teachings.

In the 18th year of Kaiyuan, at the Flower Calyx Pavilion, he debated the superiority and inferiority of the two teachings in the presence of the emperor. His majestic arguments were as vast as the overflowing of a river or the pouring of the ocean.

Later, he composed The Five Gates of the Dharma Treasures of Mahayana Buddhism and The Rituals of Faith in the Dharma, each in one volume, The Commentary on Consciousness-Only in six volumes, The Commentary on the Lotus Sutra in six volumes, and The Commentary on the Diamond Sutra Annotated by the Emperor in six volumes.

At first, when Xuanzong annotated the sutra up to If there are people whose past sins should lead them to fall into evil realms, up to the point where their sins are then eliminated, although he used the brush of a rabbit, he had quite a bit of doubt, fearing that he would give rise to erroneous understandings, or perhaps make interpretations that differed from other masters.
The emperor then ordered Yin to decide the power of the scriptures and to analyze right and wrong.

The students from the four seas gathered like scales, and at Qinglong Temple, when he held the new commentaries, the listeners numbered in the thousands. He also lectured at Ximing and Chongfu Temples.
The lecture halls were all made with fragrant mud, built from the water's edge to the ground level, and the splendor was the best in the capital.
In the twenty-eighth year of Kaiyuan, he was about to die, and sent his disciples to carry his last testament, saying:
I, a person of the lowest rank, lightly regarded life, vainly equal to the rain and dew, was able to accompany the black-robed assembly, and allowed myself to cultivate diligently.
Although I always bared my right shoulder, I had no duty to raise my sleeves.
But holding the staff and stretching out my steps, I was able to avoid the labor of carrying burdens.
It is said that at this time, the profound merit is fully realized, and the virtue of the true teaching is exalted;
I did not expect that in diligently striving to learn, one would be nourished in a moment of carelessness.
On the sixteenth day of this month, my painful intestines suddenly worsened, and medicine and soup could not save me.
